name: Controller Companion
description: Navigate your PC desktop with a controller! Put mouse, media and keyboard control in the palms of your hands so you'll never have to leave the couch again!
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 Additional Notes: Also required is an XInput compatible controller. If you have a wireless Xbox 360 controller you'll also need an Xbox 360 Wireless Receiver.

reviews.review_text: Summary: If you have some change to spare and are a gamer who likes being comfortable on the couch for non-keyboard games, STOP READING AND ADD THIS TO YOUR CART!!  Necessary for the controller or couch based gamers. Period.   Obviously, not made to be able to play keyboard-only games, but this eliminates the hassle of using a wireless keyboard or traversing to the desktop to make some KB+B changes.  I personally have a Logitech TV730 for this problem (love it!) and have tried using custom controller schemes to take the reins of windows, but so far this is the simplest launch-and-use app I've seen. Simple. Creative. Works.  I wouldn't pay for it, but to support the devs in finally--ephasis on FINALLY--making something like this, $3 is not a blood sacrifice to any diety. LOL  Disclaimer: Is not for everybody. Is not for MMO players or programs and games that REQUIRE a keyboard. Only best for couch gaming a la console or laziness. Have only tried it with an XB360 controller, though, I do not see why other wouldn't work.

Controller Companion makes couch gaming/surfing experience like a breeze & this software does a quite an impressive job differentiating from other freeware/paid 'Controller>Mouse apps' Great job developers, you guys really redeem yourselves with a quality product here.   *Pros*  + Unique Spiral keyboard. Effectively, this feature extends your Big Screen game library since this allows u to play your point n' click games & VNs easily with your controller.

This program works perfectly! I use Xbox 360 Wireless Controller For Windows.  Before buying this program I had some concerns, but no worries, the developer really has thought everything through.  Even without Big-Picture the program turns off so you can play your games like you want. It works great with VLC. Doesn't turn off when using fullscreen VLC, like it shouldn't.  The 'most' unique thing about this is that you can actually turn off the controller without taking out the batteries!!  This program indeed has some neat features that are way superior than any other program out there, so the only 2 negative thing I have to say about it is that it is over 100 MB! I guess it's all the interface and the nice writing feature that holds this many bytes. It's not a problem for me, but I have been using other programs kinda like this(mouse and media features) that is only 550 KB.  As for DualShock 3 controller, DS3 (PlayStation 3 controller), it does work! You just have to use MotioninJoy, DS4Windows doesn't work for DS3, only DS4. It also work through MotioninJoy when I use my bluetooth dongle, but I will have to shut down Controller Companion first, because when I take out the USB-wire from my DS3, so it's only connected with bluetooth, Controller Companion thinks that the controller is disconnected even though it isn't, it works fine in games, but can't use CC. So shut down CC, connect with bluetooth, turn on CC and CC works fine with bluetooth connected DS3 controller.  ^I don't know if that is something that the developer from CC can actually fix, seems hard, but I hope they will.  Controller Companion FTW.  Also, it was so hard to write this review because Steam doesn't record when you use the program, only for 2 seconds. I had to turn it off and on 150 times or more oO Don't say I didn't work for this review! lol

Thanks to the new Controller Companion, my life has changed. I was looking for a cheap alternative to a girlfriend and now I've found one. It's flexible, easy to configure, no audio feedback, no artificial intelligence, and no waiting for it to get ready. I do believe I will have to get use to the feeling of the new nipples, after-all, the xbox 360 controller analog stick does flex a bit more than the standard nipple that comes with a female, but I think this will be an alright substitute. (I highly don't recommend telling your girlfriend that her nipple reminds you of an xbox 360 controller).   All in all, great substitute. 10/10 - would play with again.  [On a serious note] It is a great program for anyone who wants to use an xbox360 / xbox one controller for gaming. Very configurable. The program itself uses very little system resources. Only thing to pay attention to is that when you install it, steam records it as you always being 'in-game' with 'Controller Companion'. So your time will always go up if you have the program installed, even if your controller is not plugged in. But hey, it's $3.00, is that really a decision-making factor?  [Update] In-Game fix thanks to bnscv  - Open Controller Companion on Steam - Set the program to startup with Windows on the settings - Close CC - Go to the folder \SteamLibrary\SteamApps\common\Controller Companion and open ControllerCompanion.exe - Done, CC will open with Windows, will be always ready, and no more 'in-game' indication on Steam!  Regards, Richard YouTube: IAMRichardT

This app is great, but there seems to be bugs after I customize the bindings: 1. If the LT bind key is Ctrl (default), there is no problem, but if I bind the LT to other keys (e.g: Del), it will act as if the LT is holding down all the time, deleting my text. Happened to all of my controllers so I think this is the app's fault. 2. The 'Show virtual keyboard' is bound to L-Stick by default, so, obviously, pressing it once, the spiral keyboard will be shown, pressing it again, the spiral keyboard will be closed. However, if I bind another controller key to 'Show virtual keyboard', pressing that controller key, the spiral keyboard will be shown, but pressing it again will do nothing, to close the spiral keyboard, I have to press the L-Stick, as if the show and the close one are two different keys and you can only bind the show one, the close one will always be L-Stick.  TL;DR: The LT if bind to some other keys not Ctrl, it will act like it was holding down all the time; 'Show virtual keyboard' can be bound to another controller key, but to close it, you will have to press the default key (L-Stick),  Hopefully you guys can fix these bugs.  EDIT: Devs have fixed the first bug, and I have a workaround with the 2nd one by editing the cfg file so yeah, no more problem :D I'm gonna say this is the best app for peeps who wanna ♥♥♥♥ their pc up with a controller

If your mouse is out of reach more often than not and you are willing spend 3 extra bucks, get this beautiful piece of software and add some quality of life functions to your couch gaming. I decided that I would write my first (ever!) review on Steam for controller companion. This will be a short one.  TL;DR: 9.9/10 absolutely fantastic, controller users, purchase immediately.  The purpose of this software is to bridge the mouse/controller gap, much like a Steam controller would. And to that end, it works perfectly. This is ideal for 'couch gaming' or for those of us whose computers are within reasonable reach of the bed - you can easily cruise through videos and webpages without ever going to the computer itself. In the past, I had accomplished this with very long mouse+keyboard cords, but I would have to say this is preferable.  Pretty much everything has been thought out here, with shortcuts mapped to logical places and an easily accessible help guide to rectify any misunderstandings that may arise about the controller functions. I might go so far as to call its design 'perfect' in this regard, or in other words: I've been using it for twoish weeks, and am finding new ways to be impressed with it all the time.  The only weakness of controller companion, if you can call it that, is its inability to replace the functions of both the mouse and keyboard. That's not to say that it doesn't try admirably, indeed, it does. And the keyboard popup is beautifully designed, to the point where sometimes I bring it up just to see it. But just due to the physical limitations of the controller, it can't be a keyboard replacement. I don't consider this a flaw because the developers did their absolute best to bridge the gap, and they really did quite a nice job at it, considering.  A final note I'd like to make is that controller companion handles alt+tab beautifully. You might've thought that a software which essentially has to register a connect/disconnect as it shifts the input between 'mouse' and 'controller' modes would have some fudge ups, but I've encountered none. And when I say that, please understand that I'm alt+tabbing like 50-100 times daily if I'm gaming. It has never, ever, had an issue. It's glorious. I've come to really like the USB connect/disconnect sound as I tab around-- it just reminds me of what a great software this is.  For $3, it's a heck of a lot of bang for your buck. Consider all the other things $3 would buy, and then consider that this thing offers far more convenience than any of those things. The only hassle I ever encountered was needing to find a way to be 'in-app' long enough to post this review (since it runs in background). This is, of course, not the dev's fault. Do I recommend it? Yes, absolutely I do.

Finally I glitched the software out somehow into steam recognizing it running for more than 5 minutes.  This program was exactly what I was looking for around the time it came out and I couldn't be more pleased. Controller companion allows you to use any driver supported controller to control your mouse cursor and keyboard. It is eternally useful for those who want to couch game or use their PCs as a media center with their TV but don't want to keep a wireless keyboard and mouse around for aesthetic or battery or whatever reasons.  The keyboard is accessed via a spiral menu - on a 360 controller the default is pressing the left stick. This also leads to the one and only problem I've encountered with the software. Some PC games do not work well and natively support controller, as we know, so for those games you need to launch controller companion. However, for those games that do, and you have CC running when you eventually press left stick as part of the games control scheme - or on accident if you're a dumbass like me - it opens up the keyboard menu in the background and then it will constantly switch your control input between keyboard and controller until you alt tab and close the text menu. I don't know if this has been fixed yet but I don't think. Resident Evil 6 is a prime example of this and it makes it quite difficult to play if it happens.  Mouse operation, again on Xbox pad, is handled by right stick and A to left click. I am not sure of right click. Other than that, there seems to be a bit of a dead zone when you first try to move the mouse but I'm not so sure that's the software's fault.  CC also supports custom schemes and the workshop has blown up with them since it released. So you no longer have to use dodgy crap like Pinnacle Game Profiler that costs like 5 times more than this and doesn't necessarily even work.  This is $2. You won't find a better solution for controllers. Trust me, I've looked - I've used Xpadder, Pinnacle Game Profiler, neither one of them compares.  11/10 would get frustrated with text menu again.

Call me crazy for dropping $3 on a program that does what Xpadder did for free.  See, for the price of a cup of coffee, I got a product that worked 'right out of the box'.  Some features that this program has over the likes of Xpadder:  1. It comes pre-loaded with an intuitive control scheme for the Xbox 360 controller, identical to what I'd set up myself using XPadder. It's worth looking into the settings at first just to be sure of what everything does, but it does pretty much everything you'd expect with buttons to spare.  2. You can change all of the bindings, and this software works from the controller first. In other words: with this you bind your macros to the buttons, whereas with the likes of Xpadder you assign buttons to existing keyboard inputs. It sounds like a small difference, but it means that this software is purpose-built to let you control your computer with a controller.  3. This program sits in the system tray (out of sight) and automatically disables itself when you start playing games. It also has your Xbox button bound to Steam Big Picture. This means that right from the moment you install it, you can launch Big Picture mode and transition seamlessly into and out of controller-enabled games. I'm pretty sure that with some fiddling, you can bind certain button combinations to automatically start Netflix or pull up Google for a quick search.  That's why I was willing to pay for this software, and I think that you should too if you're someone interested in couch gaming. It's much easier to use than the available free software, and it comes with enough functionality to do just about anything you want.
